[h1]A bird story[/h1]

A short and cheap game that sadly doesn't really bring much with it to deserve a price tag.

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
I'll make it quick on this one: The Gameplay really isn't, what this game wants to do, it wants to tell a story. Basically you go to a certain point and watch the next cutscene play. The most intense part is you pressing up and down at the same time to shred some bread.

[b]The story:[/b]
And within the story lies the problem of 'a bird story', as it may not be bad, but sure is boring. Basically you play a kid, who [spoiler]finds a bird that has hurt his wing and then cares for it. The bird proceeds to get healthy, but the boy develops an unhealthy obsession for the bird, which leads to him jumping to his death, killing himself and the bird. Strangely both survive and the bird then gets captured by another bird and in what can only be described as a stockholm syndrom the bird then falls in love with it's capturer. The game ends by giving a happy end, as the bird visits it's boy once more.[/spoiler] The game also features two scenes, which have absolutely no impact on the story and just lead to nothing, as [spoiler]you walk around in a strange time-loop-thingy, probably seeing your favourite moments of life before you die (which would make the life of the boy a very sad life)[/spoiler].

[b]Music, graphic and technical stuff:[/b]
The music is what you would expect, much piano and repetition, the graphic... I mean, you can see that yourself. The technical side really pulls the game down, as movement is very clunky and I couldn't even get the game to start, when another game was running in the background (sorry fellow idle-gamers).

[b]Summary:[/b]
The game may have worked as a cute video (with better graphics for sure), but not as a game. I got nothing out of it, but perhaps some people are looking out for a nice little story about friendship or so and want to spend a quiet hour - then this one is for you. If this is worth a buck for you, then you can certainly spend it worse than on 'a bird story'. But if you are looking for a deep story, you can even find much better games in the developers catalogue within the 'To The Moon' series. Basically play that one instead.

145887856.review:
I just have to say that this developer became one of my IMMEDIATE favorites. The price tag is well justified and I would encourage anyone who likes a great story to jump on this one - and the others (To The Moon, Finding Paradise, and Imposter Factory) IMMEDIATELY. This is a series you NEED in your library.

The thing that makes these titles so special is the fact that they're very thoughtful and have complicated storylines, and they run the gamut of content - from light and funny, to dark and serious, to hopeful, heart-broken, upset, happy, and everything in between. This series is one of those that when you start one of the games, you just won't be able to stop until it's finished, and each one has a lot of content/story. Once you start playing, you'll be gripped by it and just HAVE to know how things turn out.. and you'll probably sit there playing until it's done. AMAZING, AMAZING stories.

Basic concept (which, I don't think this will be a spoiler, but I'll hide it anyway): [spoiler] Ever had something you know you're going to regret on your deathbed? Maybe you wish you had done this thing, or made that choice. Now your life is over, and you're regretting how things turned out. What if there was a way to truly believe you HAD done that thing or made that choice? The company Dr. Watts and Dr. Rosalene work at does just that - on your deathbed, they burrow into your memories, find out what makes you tick, and implant a series of new memories into your head - overwriting the old memories - so that as you pass away, you do so happy with the way things turn out.[/spoiler]

The great thing about each story is diving into it, figuring out what makes each character tick, finding out all about them... and it's told in such an amazing way. I can't tell you enough how fantastic this developer is at telling stories.

My recommendation is to play them in order. While each episode is a "self-contained" episode, it really benefits the player to play them in order. Kinda like how if you watch different episodes of your favorite TV show... sure, each show might be a self-contained story, but you don't get the full context unless you watch them in order.

To The Moon
Finding Paradise
A Bird Story
Imposter Factory

Some folks might disagree and say A Bird Story should come before Finding Paradise, since it sorta comes chronologically before FP... But one of the things that makes each story great is "getting to know" the people involved... and I feel like "A Bird Story" is better viewed as the "deleted scenes" of a movie, rather than as a prequel. If you watch the deleted scenes on a DVD first, maybe it won't "spoil" the movie, but it just doesn't feel right. Play FP first, and then dive a little deeper with ABS.

Get all 4 of these immediately. This is one of the few storyline games that got me a little choked up. I absolutely LOVE the characters and every bit of these stories was phenomenal. I couldn't possibly recommend them any more. They are well worth the full price. I had... SO much fun, and I am ANXIOUSLY awaiting the next chapters from this developer. STUNNING story. Easy gameplay. VERY... very moving.

Kan Gao's "A Bird Story" is a pixel-art short story that follows the success of "To The Moon." 
While it lacks dialogue, the game impressively crafts a deep and memorable tale. The story revolves around a young boy and an injured bird, the story leaving a profound impression on myself despite its short length.

The wordless storytelling showcases Kan's craftsmanship, utilizing subtle expressions and music to convey the narrative. The captivating tone keeps players engaged throughout, with unexpected surprises like a Benny Hill Show reference. Character development is strong, fostering quick attachment to the cast and showcasing Kan's storytelling prowess.

Gameplay is minimal, leaning towards an interactive visual novel style. While lacking puzzles and extensive dialogue like "To The Moon," the interconnected locations prevent wasted time and create a dream-like experience.

Visually, "A Bird Story" maintains the charming old-school RPG aesthetics of "To The Moon," with stunning portraits and backgrounds that become even more impressive towards the end. The instrumental soundtrack, masterfully composed by Gao, complements the wordless nature of the game, transporting players back to memorable moments.

Rather than a sequel, "A Bird Story" demonstrates the importance of artists venturing into new territory. Kan Gao delivers a truly wonderful experience that will touch players' hearts and is worth the investment. While eagerly awaiting the next game, it's evident that the wait after "To The Moon" was worthwhile. Prepare for an emotional journey that may require a tissue or two. 

I masterful piece I highly recommend to those who love a good story with self interpretation and an amazing soundtrack.

132415266.review:
[h1] A Bird Story - A Meditation On Loneliness [/h1]

In their debut title, To the Moon, Freebird Games showed how adept they are at telling a heartfelt and emotional story. This style of storytelling continues with A Bird Story, a minisode bridging the gap between To the Moon and Finding Paradise.

[h2] A Boy And His Bird [/h2]

When we meet the young boy, he's living the typical life of a latch-key kid. His day consists of waking up, going to school, returning home, doing homework, and going to sleep.

For all intents and purposes, the boy is alone. Sure, there's a parent present, but the only sign of their existence is the notes they leave for the boy.

To escape the tedium of his daily routine, the boy spends his time making paper planes and daydreaming about flying away. One day after school, this routine is interrupted when he rescues an injured bird. The boy takes it upon himself to take care of his new friend and nurse it back to health.

Thus begins a story of loneliness, friendship, and belonging. Much like To the Moon, the narrative isn't likely to blow your mind or shift your entire worldview, but it is told with absolute sincerity, nuance, and deep emotional resonance. Even though someone more cynical might consider its message of "if you love something, let it go" to be a cliche, that doesn't make it any less true.

[h2] Scenes From a Dream [/h2]

The entire narrative is told purely through visuals, without writing or dialogue of any kind (there's even a fakeout where it looks like you'll see one of the notes left for the boy, but the letters are blurred beyond recognition). When the characters do have something to communicate, they do it through comic-strip thought bubbles with simple images.

Playing A Bird Story feels a lot like watching a dream. Many of the events aren't meant to be taken literally, and the game makes frequent use of "dream logic" by condensing and expanding space and time for narrative purposes.

Like To the Moon, the pixel graphics look like the game was made in RPG Maker. The display resolution is still stuck at 640 * 480, but the scrolling is noticeably smoother than in To the Moon. The music is also pleasant and unobtrusive and acts more like wallpaper - supporting the scene playing out rather than informing your emotional response.

[h2] Point and Click [/h2]

A Bird Story plays like a super-simplified version of a point-and-click adventure. This means that you'll spend most of the game moving the boy around using the mouse or arrow keys. Interacting with objects isn't all that frequent, and when it does happen, the objects that require your attention are clearly marked.

Aside from some special prompts (like pressing two keys at once to perform an action), that's pretty much it. There are no puzzles or challenges that would take away from you simply experiencing the narrative.

From the two control schemes, using the mouse is clearly superior. It gives you more precise control of the main character and makes it easier to hit the interactive objects.

One major downside is that you can't pause the game during cutscenes, instead having to wait until you regain control of the main character. This isn't a huge problem since the game isn't all that long, but can be annoying if you have to quickly step away from your PC.

[h2] Worth Your Time [/h2]

Even though A Bird Story is noticeably shorter than any other Freebird Games title, I still think it's well worth your time. It tells a poignant story in an appealing way, and honestly, that's more than you can say for most modern games.

[b] TLDR: [/b] A short point-and-click adventure about a boy and his bird friend.
[b] Pros: [/b] Emotional storytelling, pleasing audio-visual design.
[b] Cons: [/b] Not very interactive, difficult to pause.

[h3] Final Score: 7/10 [/h3]

[quote][b]S U M M A R Y[/b][/quote]

[u][b]A Bird Story[/b][/u] is a short and silent interactive RPG from the [u][url=https://store.steampowered.com/franchise/FreebirdGames]To the Moon franchise[/url][/u]. Although it chronologically takes place before [u][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/337340/Finding_Paradise/]Finding Paradise[/url][/u] and adds some backstory to that game specifically, you can easily skip it since it isn't a necessity. Overall, I don't recommend it because it barely has any gameplay elements, the silent aspect paired with the minimal player interaction makes its one-hour playtime overstay its welcome, the story is more sentimental and emotional rather than thrilling and captivating, the game is lacking the cast that really makes the franchise shine, and the game isn't a necessary component to the franchise as a whole.

[hr][/hr]
[quote][b]A C H I E V E M E N T S[/b][/quote]

The game has a single achievement which is acquired when you beat the game. A normal playthrough takes one hour so it's pretty easy to get — you'll just have to put the time in.

[hr][/hr]
[quote][b]R E V I E W[/b][/quote]

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]
The gameplay is almost non-existent. Although it technically is an interactive RPG, the only things you'll do are walk around and occasionally interact with a few objects here and there. Otherwise, you're just along for the ride and it's more akin to watching a silent movie rather than playing an actual game.

[h3]Graphics[/h3]
The graphics are nice to look at and use 16-bit pixel art. The character sprites are very well animated and this helps convey the emotion of the story since there is no text in the game besides some speech bubble emotes. The game also has some lovely landscape pictures which would make for great wallpapers.

[h3]Sound[/h3]
The music is mostly composed of soft atmospheric songs (including some soft piano songs) which help set the mood and tone of the various scenes. None of the songs stood out in particular though.

[h3]Story[/h3]
The story is the main focus of the game and the sentimental and emotional tale helps give some backstory to the main character. As previously mentioned, there is no text in this game and you're basically watching a silent movie so it will take a bit of getting used to. Most of the scenes are actually mind-bending and baffling, heavily blurring the line between fiction and reality, and this might make you question some things about the main character.

Although the game is charming in its own way, and also has a few funny moments, I find that the absence of the original cast from [u][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/206440/To_the_Moon/?curator_clanid=2750327]To the Moon[/url][/u] really detracts from the game because it lacks the well-written script, hilarious jokes and puns, and likeable characters that are among the franchise's strong suits. I also found that story didn't really move me and I started to lose interest by the last 10 minutes of the game because it felt like it was dragging on unnecessarily. Since I am also more invested in the franchise's overall worldbuilding than I am the individual games' stories, I had even less of an interest in this game since it basically has no tie-in to the current-day world used in the rest of the franchise.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
Overall, I don't recommend it unless you really enjoy sentimental and emotional stories, you really like animal-nursing stories, you want to have even more backstory for [u][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/337340/Finding_Paradise/?curator_clanid=2750327]Finding Paradise[/url][/u], or you're just an avid fan of the franchise. It's not a bad game by any means but I don't think it stands up to the rest of the franchise and it certainly isn't a game for everyone.

That being said, if you purchased it and weren't happy then [b]Freebird Games[/b] offers a very generous refund policy which you can find here: [u][url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/327410/discussions/0/613941122665882456/]Freebird Games' purchasing policy[/url][/u]. Despite my negative review, I have no intention of refunding the game in order to support the developer since they make amazing games otherwise.

I also found the plot, while charming and visually interesting, to be a bit predictable and saccharine, something along the lines of a "Full House" episode.

Another issue I have is that this game's plot ends up revealing TOO much; I can't help but feel like I ended up spoiling the plot of "Finding Paradise" for myself. It's clear that they want this game to be set in the same universe as "To the Moon" and present it in a similar way. The problem is they do it beat for beat, and I was quickly putting together what will happen in "Finding Paradise". The plotline in this game is the earliest memory, and the motivation, for the client in the next game, "Finding Paradise," most likely after being altered by Dr. Rosalene and Dr. Watts, meaning they fulfilled his final wish. At the time of writing, I haven't played "Finding Paradise", but I now know that's exactly whats going to happen, which will take away from the mystery and suspense of my first playthrough of that game. It's fine to make an in-between game that gives hints, clues, and gets the player excited for the next mainline entry, but not at the cost of giving away the ending. It defeats the purpose of playing the next game in the series. I feel like this should've been an unlockable bonus mode included in "Finding Paradise" that you play after finishing the main campaign.

As I mentioned in my "To the Moon" review, this is a plot that would work better as a cartoon or a comic, not an interactive video game; because it just ends up being a tour through set pieces that keeps the player on autopilot throughout their playthrough. Actually playing the game and interacting with the environment or NPC's is too limited and brief. Just like the previous game, I recommend that you watch a "Let's Play", and buy the soundtrack on the developers' Band Camp page, instead.

The game is only five dollars, but you'll regret spending even THAT much, and wish it was only a free demo.

122699670.review:
A hard down-thumb for this "game".  I love Freebird's games, but this is not a game.  It's a movie, interspersed with brief and useless moments where you're given the choice between (A) walking in the direction you're supposed to walk, or (B) not walking in the direction you're supposed to walk.

There is no save option.  I'd give it a down-thumb just for that.  I quit nearly an hour into it, and am deleting it from my account, because I'll never suffer through those 50 minutes again just to find out what might happen next.

It's artfully told, but
(A) It is a story so gentle and cute that it's boring.
(B) You don't find out a single interesting thing in the first half hour of "play". You're just forced to walk here and there, with no idea who you are, what you should be doing, or why you should care. Nothing you do in this time has any significance.
(C) You have NO AGENCY at all.  Whenever you get to anything mildly interesting, the computer seizes control of your character and walks it through it.
(D) You aren't even given anything to figure out.  Even when you're doing pointless background-noise tasks, the computer tells you exactly what to do, with icons and arrows.

My guess is that the intent behind this game is for you to spend the first half-hour sympathizing with the main character because he/she has NO ONE in his/her life.  All the other children are just shadows, non-entities, and the kid's parents apparently sneak in only at night, to leave food in the refrigerator and notes on its door.  No one but this one bird.

But I DON'T sympathize with someone who has no one in his life despite having people all around him.  Maybe if I were autistic--not ASD as in "I like to stay indoors and play videogames", but Murderbot-Diaries-level autism--I'd sympathize with this character, and find A Bird Story a moving work of art.  But as I am, I could empathize with this character only if I'd been told about his/her handicap.

I really don't like leaving negative reviews, but this game was beyond underwhelming-- to the point where I was getting frustrated at how long it was taking to end.

I'm really surprised after playing because the reviews are pretty great overall. Even though I went into A Bird Story expecting literally nothing because I bought it on sale just to get an easy 100% completion, I thought maybe it could be interesting to play. As it turns out, there is very little playing involved and I found that I was sort of forced into paying attention so I could at least try to make it through this in a decent amount of time.

That didn't bother me though! I still generally enjoy these types of games, so I tried to keep an open mind as things were getting started.

Unfortunately, I felt like it was kind of boring and my playtime is only as high as it is because I needed to take so many breaks to do something else because I couldn't focus or find it in me to care. You pretty much spend most of the game meandering around to activate cut scenes and if you're [i]really[/i] lucky, you occasionally get to press the space bar!

I think all of the player "interaction" could be removed and the game would be exactly the same, as far as the mood and how you're meant to feel about everything goes. I'm actually not even sure why there was anything added to try to get the player involved at all because it was so simple and there were zero repercussions for failing any events in the game. For example, [spoiler]when you sneak the bird into your apartment building,[/spoiler] there's some kind of 'stealth mini-game' that just pushes you off to the side if you get caught and allows you to proceed without any problems. I don't see the point of having something like that in the game if it's meaningless.

There were some things I liked about A Bird Story though. The overall plot was fine and the way certain areas would blend into others to show a transition between scenes was neat. The art (especially the backgrounds [spoiler]when you do the flying segment with the nests[/spoiler]) was nice and the music was decent enough and even sometimes enjoyable.

I think the biggest flaw was that throughout the entire the game, there were no difficult choices to make (there are actually no choices at all) and there is no dialogue. I recognize this wasn't exactly meant to be a game and I know that plenty of amazing stories can be told without words, but I don't think this is one of them. 

This game felt more like it had no idea what it was trying to be and the only reason I think A Bird Story gained any traction at all is because of To The Moon and if it was made by anyone else, no one would be leaving positive reviews on this.

I wish that I had felt something at the end of this game, but all I could think about was how glad I was to be able to uninstall and forget that this exists.

107103937.review:
If A Bird Story were an animated short—and it mostly is—it wouldn’t be a very good one. The hour-long game tells the story of a lonely boy who rescues an injured bird, befriends the bird, and eventually learns that if you love something, and it’s a bird, your story is probably heading toward a terribly clichéd conclusion.

Though it’s only an hour, the hour drags. There are sweet little moments—the boy suspiciously peeking out to his balcony as the bird pops in and out of a bush—but most of the scenes are soporific, only superficially interactive, and only occasionally interactive at all. Everything takes far too long to play out, showing me too much to say too little; I don't need to be present as every page of a notebook is torn out, for instance.

As for control, developer Freebird Games—also responsible for the much acclaimed To the Moon—is honest about what A Bird Story is: “an interactive pixel animation with the sole purpose of telling a simple story.” It is simple, and it is interactive, in that I got to pointlessly walk around and pick up items on my own for a bit. But it wrested control from me so often it had to flash the arrow keys (not remappable) every time I was supposed to do the moving, otherwise I wouldn’t know.

Being such a hands-off experience isn’t an instant negative, as holding back interactivity can enhance the moments when it’s returned. It doesn’t work here. Except in a couple of scenes, my interactions did little to complement the story, or foster empathy toward its characters.

Even so, I was always clawing for those interactive moments, because the time spent watching was so boring and hokey that I just wanted it over. A Benny Hill chase scene and out-of-place Mario reference give you a sense of how banal it is. Perhaps those were attempts to characterize the boy as playful despite his isolation and self-absorption, but they come off more like cute gags. And when it's not being cute, the pixel art animation isn’t especially fun to watch. The boy's crude walking animation, for instance, kicks in moments after his sprite starts moving, and watching him slowly plod around is tiring.

For a few minutes out of the hour, I did feel A Bird Story come close to succeeding. I appreciated the lightly surreal world, especially. Other characters are shadows of people, and locations aren’t logically connected or constructed; they’re more like shorthand for places, a world built out of fading memories. If A Bird Story had used its world to say something interesting about memory or the isolation of a latchkey kid, I’d appreciate it a lot more. It does present some sincere childhood feelings—I liked hopping in puddles, the way school drags on, and how loneliness is patched with fantasy—but it just sort of looks at those feelings. And then throws a bird in.

Flying over imaginary landscapes is briefly liberating, and I liked some of the pixel art, especially the grass, foliage, and floating hunks of earth. The backgrounds, however, look sloppy (in an intentional, but not attractive way), and they’re all off-perspective with the foreground. They aren’t animated, either, so waterfalls are frozen in time. Meanwhile, creator Kan Gao’s music may be well-composed, but its neverending plunking of bells and strings is too saccharine for my tastes. All of these things could be defended as stylistic decisions, but I find little to like about them.

Several scenes take place on this balcony, and it just isn't very attractive.
As a film, A Bird Story is slow, dull, and sentimental. It’s the kind of mawkish story Disney can get away with in shorts such as ‘Feast,’ because Disney’s shorts are A) actually short and B) beautifully crafted. And this isn't a film: it's software that seems to have no interest in being software. There are no options whatsoever. You can hit Alt-Enter to send it to windowed mode, for instance, but it always starts fullscreen.

Many of these criticisms could be made of the much better To the Moon, with its identical engine and very similar style, but it’s much better regardless. Clicking through dialogue choices and wandering around make me feel present in its story—something A Bird Story mostly lacks—and it’s poignant without being too schmaltzy. It’s also much funnier.

To Freebird’s credit, it offers “no-questions-asked” refunds, even if its games just aren't “your cup of tea.” I think a cup of tea might have been nicer. I don’t enjoy clobbering the work of a spirited independent developer, but A Bird Story isn't a good example of the storytelling I know Freebird is capable of. I enjoyed a few moments of expressive animation and sweetness—playing it wasn't a harrowing experience, just not a good one—but got to the credits feeling disappointed. It ends with a teaser for the upcoming ‘Finding Paradise,’ and that’s what the whole thing feels like: a very bloated teaser for another, possibly better interactive animation. In the meantime, go play To the Moon.

[h1]A beautiful tale of friendship and appreciation towards our surrounding[/h1]

Unlike any other games, [i]A Bird Story[/i] is told visually, relying on subtle animations, and deliberate art design to craft an effective and evocative narrative. 

This very shyness is illustrated through subtle, yet effective moments. When sharing the elevator in his apartment building with another tenant, he is shown taking a tiny sidestep away from them before reaching his floor. At the start, he can step right through the other children in school, treating them like invisible beings rather than friends or even tangible peers. They are all small moments, but completely effective in silently providing some insight into the boy’s personality.

Music and audible cues also play a major role in the storytelling, often setting the tone and helping bolster the emotion in different scenes. Using light, airy piano riffs, varied guitar chords, and a wide array of woodwind and string instruments, the music is poignant and evocative without ever crossing into cheesy or undeserved territory. Kan Gao’s music serves as a necessary co-narrator to [i]A Bird Story[/i]’s unique pixelated visuals.

[i]A Bird Story[/i] is like a breathtaking sunset: short, beautiful, and leaving you wanting more. If you are a fan of To the Moon or other plot-heavy games that play on your emotions, [i]A Bird Story[/i] is most certainly worth your time.

94564243.review:
Link to review: https://backloggd.com/u/RedBackLoggd/review/279126/

Not since Virginia have I felt that I was wasting my time playing a video game from the very beginning as I did with A Bird Story. This title has been marketed as a major miniature release in the To the Moon franchise, acting as a transitionary point between the first and second entries. And yet, if I hadn’t been told that, there is no way that I would have known. A Bird Story isn’t quite a misfire, but nor is it experimental: it’s another substandard, overly-cinematic excuse for a video game that should be looked upon as an example of what NOT to do in indie game design.

You’re supposedly given the ability to move around like in TTM, but I’d say the game only unlocks that about 50% of the time. The other 50% you’re forced to watch mini-cutscenes of an abysmal narrative that I’ll tear into in a little bit.

99 percent of this movement is just basic UP/DOWN/LEFT/RIGHT, though that 1% comes up in the form of gimmicks that are too short-lived to be impactful. TTM didn’t have much in the way of gameplay either, but at least the story was intriguing, and exploration was encouraged. That latter part isn’t available here because you’re essentially on rails: trying to go off the straightforward path will land you against a brick wall, forcing you to backtrack and go back the way the game wants you go.

Aesthetically, A Bird Story is a mixed bag. It reuses a lot of the assets from TTM and the RPG Maker engine, but TTM was a beautiful game, and so that was far from being a bad tactic. Unfortunately, the limited environs here (a schoolground, apartment complex, and forested area) are laced with copy/pasted models (same-sized shadow figures, same-exact trees, same-exact lamps) ad nauseam. The biggest problem, though, is this weird filter that is placed over most of the game: it’s like halfway between sepia and bleach bypass. I’m guessing it was Freebird’s attempt at conceiving a unique “old-timey” feel to their storyline, but I didn’t think it fit personally due to the timeline being relatively modern.

Another graphical issue is the poor depiction of verticality. This is an inherent issue with 2D sprite games, and TTM suffered from it occasionally as well. But here, I felt that the problem was a lot more prevalent in the three places, with barriers not being distinguishable enough from regular pathways. That being said, one thing A Bird Story does remarkably effectively is combine the three places in fused sets that occur as a result of memories/dates getting combined in-story; you’ll see the schoolgrounds leading into forests, apartment doors opening into rainy exteriors, and so forth. Freebird also continues to demonstrate their ability to create unique facial expressions out of small sprite countenances, (though the smiling closed/curved eyelines was overused).

Sadly, I do have to end on a bitter note in this department, and that is regarding the constant use of white and black flashes. I get that this was done to depict time-skips and fast-forwards, but I couldn’t help but feel that, half the time, it was also done because the devs didn’t want to commit a huge budget to the project and so wanted to avoid animating sequences. But I fully concede that that is pure conjecture on my part. Either way, they were overused. Shortcuts were also taken like the lack of shadowmapping and no splashes (characters, in general, look like they’re floating on the land).

I was not a fan of the score. Gao did it himself again, yet the first half of the game incorporates these weird warble experimentations that distract rather than contribute to the scenes playing before you (the use of muted instruments, for example, or French Horns that hit notes so high they near-burst speakers). The second half is more restrained and standard, and yet that’s a bad thing because it both doesn’t stand out AND doesn’t contribute to the images at large. Flying around in your paper airplane, for example, should’ve elicited the same awe as John William’s track in ET during the bike scene.

The SFX is also barren. The exact same chirp is rehashed for your avian companion, and other things like footsteps and ambient noises are nonexistent. No dialogue means no voice acting (not that TTM had any, a big fault on its part).

Finally, we arrive at the story, and it’s such a misfire. You remember that episode of The Suite Life of Zack and Cody where Cody adopts a baby eagle? Imagine that turned completely serious and stretched out for an entire hour+ and you have A Bird Story. It’s actually worse than that: take that premise and combine it with a cliché tale of a loser kid with estranged parents becoming extroverted via a newfound friendship and you have A Bird Story.

Forgive me, but at this point I’m just tired of this archetypal narrative. We’ve seen it done with humans and animals alike a bazillion times, and Freebird doesn’t do anything different here. Thankfully, it doesn’t go into tearjerker territory, however there are blatant attempts at being heart-tugging and I just found it annoying. It’s quite possible to tell a moving story about a relationship using just imagery and music (Up and BvS’s openings are prime standards of this), but Freebird botched things here by over-relying on hackneyed tropes and story beats. The magical realism aspects aren’t bad, but it doesn’t amount to anything substantial or memorable courtesy of the aforestated weak OST and gameplay. Alongside, there are these odd momentary throwbacks to classic games/shows (Zelda, Spongebob, Mario, Scooby-Doo), and the comedic tones associated with them feel out-of-place with the drama elsewhere.

So yeah, it goes without saying that I wasn’t a fan of A Bird Story. Every single facet of it bore a noticeable problem, with its core narrative, in particular, being flawed. I have to play Finding Paradise to see just how integral it is to understanding that game, but I have a good feeling that it won’t be. It took me a little over an hour to beat the game, making the $4.00 asking price too much. Regardless, even if it was one dollar, the fact that I felt a one-hour game dragged says enough.

OK first of all, before we get any further here, [b]this is not a game.[/b] This is a short interactive film done in a pixel art style, with one pretty easy cheevo to get. If you're not looking for an easy one-hour cheevo or anything I just said is not the type of thing you're looking for, then this isn't for you. 

That out of the way, A Bird Story is a short, pixel art animated film with some interactive elements. It follows a tale as old as time - a child who has nobody to listen to him finds an injured animal (a bird in this case) in the woods and nurses it back to health, discovering confidence and friendship along the way. It ends the way you expect, it goes the way you expect. The point isn't to play a game or tell any sort of new story, the point is to experiment with the idea of an interactive film done with no words whatsoever - and this does that very, very well. It's a very sweet little story that partly takes place in the imagination of the child protagonist, with some interesting interactive segments, beautiful music, and some remarkably well done pixel animation by the team at FreeBird Games.

That's about all I can say as an outsider to the To The Moon franchise looking in. I enjoyed my time with it. It isn't gonna win any awards, it's not unique in terms of story, but it is emotional and animated very, very well. It's not easy to animate anything or tell a wordless story, but doing both is really quite phenomenal, and buying this supports the devs to make games with more meat on their bones. I think you should definitely give it a shot, especially since it's cheap at $4. Do I think it's [i]worth[/i] $4? Not really, maybe closer to $3, but that's your call friend. I do think if you like relaxed experiences this one is worth your time. If you liked FreeBird's other games, get this one. If you want an easy cheevo, get this one. If you wanna experience a cute, experimentally done film-like experience, get this one. If none of that sounds like you, I wouldn't bother or I would get it on sale, part of a bundle, etc.

I've had this sitting in my library for a really long time, and finally decided to play through it the other day.
This is honestly a really, really well made game, though I'd really consider it more along the lines of a visual novel, rather than "game". 
It's a cute story about a boy and a bird, with NO dialogue throughout the whole thing. However, despite the lack of words, the game does a really good job of telling its story and getting emotions across to you. At the end, I couldn't believe I was crying over a pixelated bird that I knew for like, an hour.
On top of that, it's incredibly beautiful. The visuals are absolutely gorgeous, especially when they show the moon and the stars.
There are some confusing bits, the developers used interesting ways to show the story, and I had a hard time understanding if certain things were really happening, or if they were metaphors. Once you get past that and just accept it as it is, then it's an enjoyable, smooth sailing ride throughout.
I also really appreciate the little bits of varied gameplay. For the most part, it's cutscenes or you moving the boy, but every now and then, you get special actions such as jumping in puddles (my personal favorite). 
While everything was done well in my opinion, I think this game excelled at really taking me back to my childhood. While I can't really relate too much to any exact situations in the story, I could through the visuals, emotions, music, etc., it was all just a very innocent, carefree feeling of "simpler days".
Overall, a really great little gem! Expect to set aside an hour or two to play through it, and keep a box of tissues handy for the (happy) tears.

[i]A Bird Story[/i] isn't really a game, and doesn't benefit from being interactive in the slightest. Indeed, its interactive bits (which are minimal) are the weakest part of it. They mostly get in the way of the story being told.

The game looks alright, but doesn't stand out very much, except for the backgrounds. It has an excellent score, which, owing to the game's short length (an hour or less) isn't as repetitious as its predecessor's, [i]To The Moon[/i]. This score truly elevates the game and its emotional beats, and it cannot be overstated how wonderful it is. 

More than anything, I admire the simplicity of [i]A Bird Story[/i]. At a time when many games can feel bloated or stretched out for no reason (another minor criticism I would level against [i]To The Moon[/i]), this game is not. It is short and focused. It tells a simple story, which truly feels drawn from the mind of a child. It is fantastically surreal, yet remains straightforward and understandable, despite the lack of text. 

The story it tells may be uncomplicated, but it tells it with the mastery one would expect from the people behind [i]To The Moon[/i]. And, if you examine it deeper, it feels (ironically) almost literary with its metaphors and themes. For example, (spoilers follow) [spoiler] the faceless version of the boy represents his darker qualities of selfishness and inability to let go, which ultimately nearly spells destruction for him and his bird-friend[/spoiler]. 

In the end, I felt emotionally touched by [i]A Bird Story[/i], and that is the best praise I can give it. It is a short and simple but meaningful experience that I was glad I had, and would recommend to everyone else.

This prequel to the second game in this series is interesting. I personally love it, but I can understand the opposing sentiment. The game is really short. There is no way around it. I finished it in a little over an hour. In all honestly, it feels like a preview trailer for the next game in the series (which it is). This game differs from its predecessor in the fact that there aren't any puzzles to engage in as you progress through the story. Unfortunately this tends to make the game feel more like a movie with unneeded interactive bits. However, truth be told, I do not really see how this differs too much from games produced by Quantic Dream, so if you like those games, this shouldn't be too far off in terms of gameplay.

If you really are looking for something more than a movie, perhaps you are better suited watching a lets play. However, if you don't mind exploring the game and taking it in for what it is, then I wholeheartedly recommend getting this gem. Even if you aren't 100% sure, but you are willing to give it a go and have some cash lying around, I definitely recommend supporting the developers of this series.

Ultimately, the fact that the game is short doesn't really detract from the overall experience. Freebird is known for their ability to tell a story and this game is no exception. I like to think of it like reading one of those books on zen. You can easily finish one in a few hours, but it lasts for days in terms of the thoughts and emotions it provokes.

Overall, I definitely recommend this game. It certainly isn't for everyone, but if you are in the mood for some feels I recommend anything by Freebird.

Análisis por apartados:
-Historia: Simple, lineal y predecible. Lo que podría haber sido el punto fuerte de este "juego" se queda en algo baladí.
+Duración: Suficiente (algo menos de hora y media). Hay que tener en cuenta que este género se aproxima más al formato audiovisual (película, serie de televisión...) que al de la definición clásica de juego.
-Jugabilidad: No es que sea difícil jugarlo... es que prácticamente no hay que hacer nada.
-Gráficos: Pixelart sin nada que lo haga destacar.
+Sonido: La banda sonora no es una maravilla, pero transmite más que la historia en sí.
+Traducción: En el juego no hay diálogos, así que puede jugarse incluso sin saber leer.
-Dificultad: No es un juego al uso, así que no hay que superar nada.
-Multijugador: No existe, ni creo que sea aplicable a este género de "juegos".
-Uso de mando: He podido jugar con mi Steam Controller porque puede emular un teclado, pero el juego no está preparado para jugarlo con mando de forma nativa.

A testament to the power of interactive narratives, visual storytelling and the versatility of the RPGMaker engine in the hands of a sufficiently talented creator, the game is less than an hour long and entirely linear, but its moving power makes it a more worthwhile experience than any number of thousand-hour open world sandboxes. I actually teared up during the climax of the game, several parts of the story almost cracked me up with their comic timing, and the dreamlike sequences with the giant paper airplane filled me with more wonder than games with a million times as much graphical power. Speaking of which, the pixel art in the game is truly remarkable, with the sprites being wonderfully expressive, and the music is the stuff you hear in your dreams. Even if you're not already invested in the To The Moon series (and you should be, it's wonderful), this is thoroughly worth the time and money. Experiences like this justify the existence of gaming.

Kan Gao's games aren't for everyone.

Every single one of his games made me cry, Finding Paradise by far the most. There's always a deeper theme, imagery, allegory and symbolism to discover. This short and sweet game deals with loneliness of a boy with an overactive imagination. It's about making hard choices and learning to let go. It's about how loss can be comforting and the meaning of a true love... It's about seeing a cruel world from the perspective of a child and trying to make it a little more beautiful.

If you are debating between this and To the Moon and Finding Paradise, definitely pick this one LAST. Though this is a prequel to Finding Paradise, it's standalone and very experimental compared to the other two. Both are masterpieces. If you like them, you will enjoy Bird Story as well.

Everyone is a child at one point in life, but only a few vividly remember what it's like. This game is like seeing the world through the eyes of a child again, how life is happy and simple, and all you really want is a friend, doesn't matter its race, sexual orientation, or even species.
This game is a rollercoaster, pretty much how a lonely kid's life is like. It can be unsettling, lonesome, but full of imagination and joy. It discusses delicate topics like busy parents raising their children and school bullying in a heartwarming way, with no words needed. I wouldn't expect less from the To The Moon developers. It's not only a game, but an experience. Its gameplay isn't the most innovative or skill-demanding, but it's a vivid story happening before you, where you can just feel the wind flowing in your face when you're flying the paper plane.
I'm a sucker for RPGM games and always will be, but they have to compensate for the lack of gameplay. This one may even change the way you view life, can brighten up your day, or at least put a smile on your face. Take a break from challenging games or deep horror RPG games and give this one a try, it'll be worth every second.

The world excellently blends what, as children, we would see. Time for mundane things like travelling to school and home are sped up, the trees seemingly paving the way, flying on a paper airplane. It all hits close to home from our childhoods. I also like how his parents were shown to care, but they were just busy, as seen with the blanket on our main character. I can definitely see where some people may not have been overly fancied with this, as you really aren't solving puzzles, exploring, or anything to distract from what is happening. Overall, I do recommend, but if you are expecting a game with problems and solutions, dungeons, puzzles, battles, etc. I would steer to something a little more your style. 52697706.review:
[h1]TGEXP Reviews: [u]A Bird Story[/u][/h1]
★★★★★

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]
The audio is one of the best features of this game. Whimsical tunes to dreary melodies, everything about the music sets the mood.

Which is a good thing, considering there is no speaking in this game. The music kind of guides you into what's happening as scenes transition from one area to another.

It's not always about the music either. Sometimes it's about the smaller sounds. Of nature, of paperwork, of school. The sounds in general go great with this game.

[h1]Navigation[/h1]
You can't wander around much in A Bird Story. Instead, you can follow a small, set path to where you're needed to go, or you watch as the main character interacts with the world before you're able to take initiative.

Navigation was a bit rough for me while using a controller, but you can also use mouse and keyboard--which is more recommended.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Nothing stands out too much as far as the graphics go, but that doesn't make the game bad or doesn't give it a charm. I've always liked pixel art in games, because they take time to create (if not using a generator, I suppose).

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
You go left, up, down, and right.

That's more-or-less the kind of gameplay you'll be dealing with. But aside from that, you'll also be interacting with objects and people.

Take note that there is no words being given toward you or others. This game is all about actions that are being taken. That's where the whole story comes into play, and it's a very nice style. Words tend to get in the way, sometimes.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
In the end, A Bird Story is a very short, but very good game that features the power of friendship and caring for others, despite them being completely different from you.

Everyone thinks about their dogs or cats as lifelong companions, but hey. Sometimes they can be squirrels, foxes, or even--you guessed it--birds.

[h1]A Bird Story -> 8/10[/h1]


First things first: you should only play this game if you're interested in To The Moon's franchise.
A Bird Story is a short childhood story of the pacient of To The Moon's sequel, Finding Paradise. So, I think this game is something you should play before playing Finding Paradise, since, from my experience, this game lets you understand many attitudes that Colin (the pacient in Finding Paradise) has, and it's also a good way to understand the plot better (but you can fully understand the plot of Finding Paradise without playing this game).

If you want a bit more details about the story: A Bird Story has as the main focus the situation of Colin. Colin is a lonely child, he doesn't have many friends, and his parents are always working, so he doesn't spend a lot of time with them. So, the story starts when Colin finds a bird who can't fly. Then you can see the friendship these 2 build, and how they'll fix one another throughout the game.

[h1]My thoughts[/h1]

As I said, I think you will have a much better experience with this game if you've already played To The Moon, or Finding Paradise, but it also can be a way for to be interested in those 2 games.

The story of this game is really beautiful, the soundtrack is on point, and it's a nice looking RPG Maker game.

One thing that I didn't like in this game was the fact that it hasn't any dialogues. Yes, all the story is told to you only by the "graphics", and so, sometimes it's hard to understand what's really hapenning in the story, and, until today, even after playing Finding Paradise, there are some parts of the story I didn't get a clean anwser to. I don't think you'll be confused with the main aspects of the plot by the end of the game. I'm essentially talking about some details.

[h1]Final Opinion[/h1]

To finish this, I recommend this game, but you should maybe buy it on sales, since it's many times on sales (like now, at the time I'm writting this), and the game is really short for 4€ (although I think the game isn't that much overvalued, but you can easily get it cheaper), Finding Paradise costs 10€, and I got 6 hours of gameplay from it, but with A Bird Story I only got 84 minutes (not even an hour and an half), and I have a really slow gameplay pace.
However, I don't think you'll regret buying A Bird Story, since it may remind you of your childhood times, and it will fill your heart with good feelings with its beautiful story.

[h1]ANÁLISIS DE "A BIRD STORY":[/h1]

En "A Bird Story" vivimos la historia de un niño en su día a día, su rutina diaria, el colegio, el camino a casa, etc. y como cambia su vida tras encontrarse con un pájaro herido con el que entabla una fuerte amistad. Argumento nada original, pero sí lo es la forma en la que está "contado" y representado. 

Si has jugado al genial "To the Moon", de los mismos creadores (puedes ver mi análisis del juego [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/razielbpn/recommended/206440/]aquí[/url]), este mantiene la misma estética y jugabilidad simple, gráficos 2D al estilo Pokémon de Game Boy pero a todo color muy agradables y simpáticos, con el mismo estilo de banda sonora con canciones de piano, pero perdiendo los geniales diálogos. Aquí no se dice ni una sola palabra en todo el juego y aunque resulta original y está bien llevado, se echan de menos los comentarios de los carismáticos personajes de "To the Moon".

A pesar de no tener diálogos, podemos interpretar muchas cosas con las situaciones que vamos viviendo, como la soledad del niño, sus problemas de atención en el colegio, el aburrimiento de la rutina diaria, su gran imaginación, etc. Más que un juego, se trata de un relato interactivo. 

Viviremos muchas situaciones surrealistas, con escenarios reales mezclados con otros fantásticos producto de los sueños y la imaginación del niño protagonista, algo que a veces puede resultar algo confuso. Poco más que comentar en una historia que no nos llevará más de una hora y media para terminarla. 

Para no extenderme más, os dejo mi lista de pros y de contras.

[h1]PROS:[/h1]

- Una historia muy bella

- La banda sonora con canciones de piano es muy bonita

- Apto para niños y adultos

- La imaginación del protagonista

- El amor por los animales

- Puede tocar la fibra a los más sensiblones

- Gráficos agradables

- Algunos escenarios son muy bellos

- Tiene cromos Steam

- En épocas de ofertas se puede encontrar a menos de 1€

[h1]CONTRAS:[/h1]

- Muy corto, en una hora y poco lo tendrás terminado

- No tiene diálogos

- Ya no sorprende tanto como lo hizo "To The Moon"

- Muy pocas posibilidades de interacción

- Mucho más simple que "To The Moon"

- No se puede acceder a la inferfaz de Steam desde el juego

- Jugabilidad demasiado básica: nos limitamos a ver cinemáticas y a usar las flechas para mover al personaje de un lado a otro realizando acciones simples

- Deja todo demasiado a la imaginación

- Tremendamente lineal

- Se podría haber profundizado mucho más en la historia

- No tiene ningún aliciente para rejugarlo

- No llega a emocionar tanto como "To The Moon"

- Solo tiene un logro

- Podrían haber añadido algo de exploración, secretos, más logros, etc.

- Final muy previsible

[h1]CONCLUSIÓN:[/h1] 

Un juego enfocado a todas las edades, con una historia muy bonita, con mensaje, con unos gráficos muy agradables, pero que no le llega ni a la suela del zapato al genial "To the Moon". En este caso no hay diálogos y las mecánicas de juego son aún más simples. Solo recomendable en época de ofertas a menos de 1€, si te gustó mucho "To The Moon" y como antesala a Finding Paradise, con el que está muy relacionado.

Si te ha gustado mi análisis o te ha servido de ayuda, te agradecería que dejaras tu valoración positiva. No dudes en dejar tus comentarios ¡gracias por leerme!

A bite-sized masterpiece from Kan Gao.

This was my first experience playing one of Gao's games. His other two titles, "To the Moon" and "Finding Paradise" are now high on my "To Play" list. 

The art in A Bird Story is lovely, the music beautiful, and the overall vision and storytelling superb. The story is minimalist (no text or dialog), yet still rich and rewarding. There's loneliness, isolation, beauty, triumph over authority, and of course wordless friendship — and kinship. The narrative artfully blends reality and imagination, creating a surreal, dream-like experience repete with magic realism. The soundscape of Gao's gorgeous music (which to me feels very "Chrono Cross" in style), blended with the lovely sound effects and heaps of birdsong, bring the story to life.

From a pure visual standpoint, something in the way Gao's creation exists on the screen feels deeply reminiscent of classic Squaresoft games like "Chrono Trigger" and "Final Fantasy III (VI)" — only with a level of artistic detail fitting of a modern presentation. Almost like I was seeing what those games looked like to me when I was first playing them all those years ago. That subtle nostalgia factor definitely contributed to my enjoyment, but if you're more recent to gaming it won't be a detriment. However, those of you who grew up with the classics will definitely know what I mean.

The only warning I'd throw out with this is that "A Bird Story" is nominally a game. It's more of an interactive story — or more accurately still — an interactive suite of music. But don't let that detract you. Playtime for me was 1.25 hrs, and the price was worth every penny. Just think of it as an interactive animated film, and your expectations will be beautifully fulfilled.

'A bird story' is the story of how avian flu spread into the human population and also of how blank 8.5 by 11 inch sheets of paper wind up blowing through city streets; All due to inadequate parental supervision.

More seriously though, A Bird Story is a tear jerker severely hampered by its pretentious and mediocre Hallmark store esq piano music and the extreme predictability of its plot. I also liked how the colors of the game world changed with the emotions of your character though this also increased the pervading sense I had of how the story's main character is a severe narcissist. I strongly recommend taking your budgie to the vet before watching this visual novel...

Personally was not aware that veterinarians could be such bad asses. It seems not only are they willing to chase you through dark forests to try and apprehend you, but they are even willing to bring the bounty hunt to your local school arranging some sort of posse/lynch mob ending with you needing to go all Butch and Cassidy and practice your cliff jumping skills.

This is a short (1.5hr) light hearted, stand alone, minisode that’s supposed to come after 'To the Moon' and a prequel to 'Finding Paradise'. The experimental story project is conveyed using visuals, music and sound with no words. It's about an unnamed boy of a single parent who has a fascination with flying. In dreams and memories we are cast back to his daily feelings of being bullied, isolated and made to feel like an outcast, only to come across a little injured bird which he can relate to since it has also been bullied by a predator.

As the boy and bird form a close bond of friendship, the matter of needing to be loved, the need to belong and the need to let go is explored. It's a colourful tale from start to finish, furnished with many liberties from a vivid childlike imagination and haphazard recollection. All brought to life with unrealistic location transitions, with nonsensical object blending like classroom lockers and trees and wild shenanigans involving giant paper planes.

While the story is presented in a fairly streamlined manner, there is a very small trivial amount of interaction required to push the story forward. Unlike 'To the Moon' however, this was never meant to be a tear jerker or something that was to be a very deep metaphor. Hence, it is best that you blank slate such notions before proceeding. With its Mario, Link, Benny Hill, Doge and To the Moon reference hidden within, it is sure to inspire a smile and chuckle here and there while maintaining and ending with a feel good notion.

While it got some bad wraps for being fairly whimsical, I seriously applaud the developer for his attention to small details, like the time on the clocks, the fact that only one side of the parent bed ever gets used. I also salute the variety of ways he tries to get messages across using shadows, sepia, black and white tones, zoom, movement, repetition and blur. A lot of love and care really went into the making of this.

However the award winning toast to this production has to be chalked to its meticulously fitted and time matched soundtrack. The way the inspired and invigorating piano, strings and woodwind instruments empower the listener to emotion while they blatantly watch characters made from the rather crude RPG Maker XP.

The Canadian developer has evidently metaphor some of his own personal feelings in this game as revealed by his company name freebirdgames.com/ , but still it's left somewhat open to every birdwatcher's interpretation. While games like this which require you to sit silently and watch may not appeal to everybody, the plumage, the call, its stretched out wingspan as it takes off has proven to many that it deserves a place on this planet.

39993377.review:
A Bird Story is the follow up to To The Moon, the critically acclaimed game from Freebird Games.   Five minutes into the game I looked this up because it feels like a massive step back, but yes, this game was published three years after the original. 

The entire game feels like a big step backwards.  While To The Moon had problems of limited interaction and linear storytelling, it was a nice 4-5 hour affair of great graphics and a brilliant story. 

A Bird Story doesn’t have that.  It does try something different in telling a wordless story.  Problem is it’s not very interesting and pretty tame.  It’s not that it’s predictable, it’s that there is nothing to predict really.  The game travels to surrealism quite often, but aside from that, there’s not much here.  You go to locations, sometimes there’s an image of things people are requesting and then you find them in the room.  

Now a dialogless game sounds interesting, but the player asks “What is he doing now.” Brushing his teeth, getting food, taking off a backpack.  It’s all done through 16-bit graphics.  Problem is it’s not really clear what the player is doing quite often so I have to ask. This feels like how Final Fantasy especially four and six did cutscenes, but there they had words to add to the scene, or at least had more game so it wasn’t reliant only on that feature.  Here, the only feature is the wordless animations.

In fact, as I played the game I often questioned “can I move” as the game sometimes takes control away from you suddenly.  Luckily the game always shows the arrow keys quickly when you can move, sadly, it feels like more of the game could have been more interactive or asked more of me.   Yet at the same time, less of the game could be interactive.  If this was just an hour long animation, it probably would be as impactful.  Well… reach the same level of impact.

The thing is the game tries to be innovative, and I’m not against that, but it also should try to be great, and it falls short.  The game only lasted about an hour, and I got bored of it really fast.  Where I LOVED To The Moon’s story, I felt very little here.  Innovation is only good when it’s successful.  No one should be applauding the guy who built an automated car that falls apart or crashes quickly.   A Bird Story isn’t broken… it’s just not very entertaining and both too short and too long. 

I remember when I played Thirty Flights of Loving and HATED the game, just loathed it.  A Bird Story is better than Thirty Flights of Loving, it has great graphics, great music, and an attempt at a powerful story.  It just falls far shorter than what I would be able to recommend.  It has all the same problems.  Expensive price for the length, and poor gameplay.

However, A Bird Story has one more problem.  While it has great graphics.  I sit here in front of a 4k television and it tried to show me the game in a box that took up less than 40 percent of the screen when full screened.  The solution is to put it in windowed mode, but even then it’s still not filling up the screen, and caused another problem with the sound.  The graphics still were small, and that kind of sucked.  According to the developer, it’s a problem with RPG Maker XP.   Ok but still a decent ding against the game. 

I really want to see the art of the game and get entranced by the story, but it didn’t happen, and at the end of the day, there are far better games out there.  I don’t hate Freebird games, I loved To The Moon, I just didn’t like this one.  The good news is their next game. Finding Paradise is out and that is a longer game and more like To The Moon. 

But A Bird Story is just not a game I’ll recommend, even to people who want just “Story-based games”.  It’s not a broken game, but not a game worth playing.  However if you haven’t played To The Moon, you should go get that instead.  That game is still brilliant.

"[b]A Bird Story[/b]" is a touching interactive short story made and developed by Freebird Games. You play as a lonely young boy who befriends a bird that is injured after he rescues it from a badger. He finds companionship and friendship with this bird. For the most part you're just moving your character around and only where the game let you go. You will sometimes be tasked with hitting particular directions on the arrows to perform actions on objects, but let's be honest there isnt a challenge at all. By that I mean that the music becomes quite lively when something happy is going on and a bit dark during the more introspective moments. "A Bird Story" is a charming, emotional tale that connected me to the story and brought a few tears to my eyes. Centered around themes of loneliness, entrapment, and escapism, this short game follows the saga of a young boy that finds an injured bird in the woods and their adventure together. Lastly, I'll note again that this is a story game in the visual novel family. Some people consider these non-games, and while I find that to be very diminishing and reductive, I concede that I did more watching and thinking than actively "doing." If you don't like those kinds of games, this one probably won't be the one to break the mold for you.

A Bird Story is the next entry in line from To The Moon, except instead of playing from the doctors' perspective, you're playing from the patient's.

Understandably, this gives this game a different feel. There are no puzzles to solve or things to look for within the levels and you are quite literally guided or forced down paths. (To The Moon was linear, but there was still some poking around to be done along with simple puzzles to solve.) This makes it feel more like an interactive movie.

That said, it does focus on a mechanic we became familiar with near the end of To The Moon, which was the world changing and rearranging around the patient and the patient going on interacting with their new environment. It makes the game fascinating in certain ways.

Story-wise, it starts with a young boy going through the motions of daily life. This makes the beginning feel a little tedius, but then he finds a bird with an injured wing and delights in taking care of it. It sounds cheesy (and it is), but it makes for a lovely little piece that can be finished in about an hour.

Personally, I had to be in the right mood to enjoy this game. (I hated it the first time, but enjoyed it the second.)

If you're planning on going in with the standard set by To The Moon, don't. You'll be disappointed by default. Otherwise, I do recommend giving it a fair shot.

[h1][b]A Bird Story		* 6/10[/b][/h1]

Words are useless. You don't need them to tell a good story. This is what I learnt from A bird Story. 

[h1][i]INTRO & GAMEPLAY. What is A Bird Story about and how does it work?[/i][/h1]
See it any way you want, this is the story of a child that finds a bird in distress, or the story of a hurt bird that gets found and helped by a boy. It's a sweet short story of the relationship between these two, with trips, adventures and journeys with a child's fantasy. Maybe I said too much but it is a nice story worth being followed.
Gameplay is very simple and almost limited, it has an RPGmaker aspect, so io can move around and interact with a bunch of items and go in various maps, however there are no riddles and you're guided all the time. Because the purpose is not gameplay, but the story. And interesting enough there are no dialogue, no texts, nothing. There's no need for them.

[h1][i]GRAPHIC. Engine And Artistic aspects.[/i][/h1]
As already mentioned it has an RPGMaker aspect, so it has a retro pixel art look. There are different locations you will visit, from road, to school, forest, apartment and oter places, but they're done properly.

[h1][i]SOUNDTRACK. Themes and Accompaniments.[/i][/h1]
Soundtrack is very light but effective, mostly piano parts, and will support the different key moments along the story.

[h1][i]LAST NOTES. What doesn't work?[/i][/h1]
Not much. You need to be interested in a short and particular story to enjoy the game but that's up to you. The only problem with the game is with its launcher's glitch. Many people reported the game to stay on black screen and a message "script is hanging"  will appear. Obviously the game won't start. Developer said the issue solves itself but mine didn't. And after successfully launching the game at home and with my mobile connection I got to the conclusion that limited connections (but still connections, as steam was running smoothly and online) such as universities' wifi, will prevent you from playing. For no reason appearently, because why would the game require to obtain a connection? And why wouldn't developer not know about this? 

[h1][i]TL;DR. Pros And Cons[/i][/h1]
[h1]+++PROs+++[/h1][list]
[*][b] NICE SHORT STORY.[/b] This is a nice short story, no dialogues involved but everything is told through images and actions.

38432286.review:
[b][u]5 Things You Should Know about [i]A Bird Story[/i][/u][/b]
[b]What Is It?[/b]
A short (~1hr) indie adventure game.  I'm not sure if "visual novel" is the right term, but it tells a heartwarming story without much in the way of actual decision making on the player's part, using SNES-era retro pixel graphics and a traditional JRPG format (although I wouldn't personally call it an RPG.)

[b]What's The Best Part?[/b]
The story is pleasant, simple and touching.  Told entirely without language - only the occasional icon or animation - it has a way of engaging your interest and keeping it, because of that.  The story hearkens back to a more innocent time when we, as children, didn't worry so much about "why" or "how" and just did things because they [i]felt right[/i].

[b]What's The Worst Part?[/b]
There's nothing I didn't like about this game.  It's pretty short, so there's not a lot of time for things to get on your nerves, and there were no obvious flaws or bugs to speak of.  I guess some people might find the "no language" thing confusing at parts, but I thought it was clear enough.

[b]Will I Like It?[/b]
+ Heartwarming childhood tale
+ Unique storytelling mechanic (no text)
+ Nice music

[b]Final Thoughts[/b]
In addition to being a unique story itself, it's also an introduction to the world of the developer's other games - [i]To The Moon[/i] and [i]Finding Paradise[/i].  Each of them is standalone, so you don't [i]need[/i] to play this one first, but they are technically all connected.

This has been a 5TYSK review. (#0024)

Some things to keep in mind before buying A Bird Story:
- The engine is terrible. Objects clearly meant to be round are stretched horizontally. Alt-tab will make the sound stop working. There's no gamepad support. - It's extremely slow-paced and focused on slice-of-life storytelling. It takes a long time before there is any sort of drama or conflict, and then it doesn't last long. It's not the kind of story that tries to get you invested in the outcome, but rather tries to draw you in with moodiness.
- 100% of the interactivity consists of obeying commands the game gives you, usually brief 'go fetch a thing' repeated ad nauseum. The result feels like an indie film that you passively watch but you have to do random chores to progress through.
- As such, don't try to disobey the signposted direction the game is funneling you toward. You will slowly crawl off and eventually hit an invisible wall, and then have to endure the tedium of walking all the way back to the one and only path.

If you're okay with all that, you may enjoy this game. The art is nice and the music is overly sappy but competently composed. It may be a good option if you're really into avant-garde narrative experience type stuff.

I would not recommend [i]A Bird Story[/i] to those who think very traditionally about what "a game" must be like, because there isn't a lot of agency as a player or intricate gameplay. And I can understand some being potentially put off by that. But for what it is in fact attempting to be and is clearly advertised as - that is, an interactive short story, rather than a game in the traditional sense - it hits the mark [i]hard.[/i]

[i]A Bird Story[/i] is an experience that I'm very glad I had. It's simple, yet thought-provoking. It's down to earth, yet injected with a healthy, enchanting dose of fantasy and imagination. It's deeply emotional, yet doesn't shy away from occasional comedic moments (which, by the way, really surprised me in getting some genuine laughs out of me). It uses absolutely zero words to convey a wonderfully executed, heartfelt story of childhood, friendship, and loss. The complete lack of words of any kind (aside from the end credits) makes this equally accessible to speakers of absolutely any language and those too young or otherwise impaired in reading ability, which I think is something pretty special.

At first glance the pixel art is tiny and the animations seem like they'll be limited, but the further I got into it, the more [i]A Bird Story[/i] impressed me with how much it could do in such a small space. Being a short story gives [i]A Bird Story[/i] the freedom to have many different bespoke character sprites for each and every small moment, making it feel alive the whole way through.

The music is also incredibly deserving of praise. It swelled into emotional crescendos and faded into silence or quiet at all the right moments. It's beautiful and I am strongly considering buying the soundtrack. Calling it [i]completely[/i] devoid of gameplay also wouldn't be a hundred percent fair; a simple thing like which arrow keys to press at which moments is sometimes used in adorable and inventive ways to keep the player feeling involved.

For anyone who doesn't need absolutely everything on Steam to be gameplay-heavy, and is at all interested in just settling down for about an hour and experiencing a charming story, I would definitely recommend [i]A Bird Story[/i].

Do you value story over gameplay? Do you love games that stir up emotions? Have you loved To The Moon? If so... you might like this game, but there's a good chance it will leave you disappointed. It certainly didn't amaze me.

Right off the top: this game is short. Hell, you can probably play through the entire thing in little more than a single hour. This doesn't give you enough time to become attached to the characters or get emotionally invested in the story.

Another thing you might not expect: no dialogue. The game goes out of its way to tell the entire story with nothing but environments and visual metaphors and it certainly has some really good ideas on how to convey it. But some of the metaphors fall short of the point into obscurity and there's a limit on how complex a story you can tell this way. I'm still at loss on what actually happened at some points in the game. I wasn't shocked or surprised or touched in a deep way by anything I saw.

But what really kills this game is the interactivity, or to be more precise, the near-complete lack of it. The game is comprised of lengthy cut-scenes connected by brief and meaningless moments of interaction. It's 100% linear, no choices ever matter and all you're ever required to do is going from point A to point B and sometimes pressing the action button. It's mundane and pointless. It's anyone's guess why the game even bothers to give you control.

Overall, it's not all bad if you treat it like a (semi) interactive intro/trailer for an upcoming game, but on its own, this game doesn't have much to offer.

[quote]“In order to see birds it is necessary to become a part of the silence.”
[i]― Robert Lynd[/i][/quote]

I one word, [i]A Bird Story[/i] excels at being "heartwarming".

[h1]Foreword[/h1]
This is more of a personal tale interconnected with the game [i]A Bird Story[/i] rather than a formal review of the game in itself. [b]For the short review, skip to the last two headings.[/b]

[h1]May the 18th, 2014[/h1]
Snow doesn't fall where I live. If ever Brazil was known for falling snow, it was in the southernmost region of the land and nowhere else. May the 18th arrived, late and dressed in white, to be the exception. An inexplicable climate anomaly happened to one, and only one, neighborhood in the vast city of São Paulo: mine. 

I was running down the street from school, panting and freezing. It was far too cold for my usual garbs, cars were filling the streets in chaotic traffic and the various trees that surrounded me had shed their leaves in silent prayer after so long without rain — and no doubt after the strength of the falling hail hit them like rocks.

Out the corner of my eye I saw it: a bird buried deep in chunks of melting ice. It struggled to free itself, its little chest heaving in a show of effort. Without thinking twice, I halted on my tracks, knelt down in the ice and leaves, and took the poor trembling thing in my hands.

It felt like holding a tiny feathered heart, one that could stop beating at any second, lest I look away for a single heartbeat.

At that point I was less than 5 minutes away from my home, but that swift time saw itself doubled once I was forced to walk in a more tactful manner in order to not jolts the poor thing around.

Arriving at home felt like arriving at the emergency room of a hospital with a terminal patient dying in my arms. I ushered my mother to get a shoe box, stripped my father of his newspapers, turned the house upside-down for one of those old yellow light bulbs that grow hotter with time, found bundles of cotton and put it all together in a makeshift bed I'm all too proud of despite its hastiness in coming to life.

The bird looked like it was going to die. Its wet feathers were stuck to its tiny body like a furry dog after a long bath, making it look sickly and fragile. It was trembling and didn't even flinch away from human touch so shocked it must have been. My mother then said — and this I'll never forget:

"You know he's probably going to die, right?"

We found some recipes for home-made bird food, and fed it and watered it with a dropper. Eventually it eased its trembling under the warm light and the thermal isolation provided by the newspapers. We made holes in the shoebox and decided to leave it there overnight, with the lid closed lest the bird fly off and hit a window. I slept unsettled.

Morning arrived and mother ushered me downstairs, messy hair and all, to do the honors. We brought the shoebox to the backyard and I remember holding my breath as I slowly lifted the lid.

Witnessing it soar away was one of the happiest and warmest I've ever felt. The feeling persists.

[h1]The game[/h1]
[i]A Bird Story[/i], in its tenderness, managed to resurrect in me all these fond memories. Freebird Games have a charm in executing stories that by far exceed words and, in roughly one and a half hours, [i]A Bird Story[/i] brought me to relive from good friendships I've had and lost, to the one bird I saved during that unexpected hail storm.

I see no reason not to recommend this heartwarming game. Although some would argue its briefness is a weak point, I see it a strong one: Freebird Games knows for how long narrate a sweet tale without giving anyone cavities.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[i]A Bird Story[/i] is a short endearing story whose only major fault, according its waiting crowd, is not being as good as [i]To The Moon[/i]. Granted, it isn't, but that only goes so far as the script, in my humble opinion. The execution still sustains that signature whimsiness and tactfulness that few of us can only ever dream of achieving in any realm of our lives.
