The transitions from place to place are done in a strange way, sometimes effectively, sometimes it just looks dumb. Its backgrounds are great though, mostly.

It's in the "game" part that this game fails; the "game" to this game is no more than walking from point A to point B and ocationally pressing directions to move the cutscenes along, which was pretty weird and it felt unnatural to do so. The parts where you walked around from point A to point B also just kind of plop you in like "Hey, remember that this is a game? Good. Now roll the next cutscene." It felt especially weird with the arrow keys showing up on screen after every cutscene, even though I had been using my controller for the past half an hour. If this were to be a YouTube short film, I'd say this is good, but it's a game, for which you have to pay 4 dollars (or pounds or euros or whatever), which is a bit expensive for what it is. The game drags on for way too long at times, it gets really boring.

It certainly doesn't help that the times that you do walk around, your movement is very limited and stiff. First of all, you have to use either a controller or the arrow keys, not WASD, which isn't a big problem, but it sucks you can't just change that in the settings. In "A Bird Story" you experience the story of a boy and his new and only friend, a bird. After rescuing it from a badger he takes care of it and bonds with the bird while also keeping it safe from others and realizing that the bird must return to its own kind one day.
Think of it as a walking simulator in Super Nintendo graphic style.

If the game reminds you of "To the Moon" very much, don't worry: It is the same company "Freebird Games". 
What you see and hear is pretty much the same concept: detailed, pretty retro graphics to a beautiful piano soundtrack.
Also the story is pretty much about life itself and important parts of it, like friendship and love.

Though, I must admit that "A Bird Story" disappointed me a bit because I had very little to do and even what I could do was laughably idiotproof (go a few steps in this direction, go to that room...). Most of the time it's like watching silent cutscenes from a SNES RPG game. True, the scenes are often very beautiful and dreamlike (like when you exit your house or classroom and you find yourself in the middle of the forest or when you ride that paper plane) but after a while I felt rather bored than impressed. And after 1 or 2 hours you should finished it completely.
The bond between the boy and the bird was nice, though but not too strong or something that would be stuck in my memory anytime soon.

So: I don't know if I should recommend this game even though it's not technically bad, it just offers not much.
It's pretty and relaxing, short and cute but no must-have. If you haven't tried out "To the Moon" yet, better check that out first.

This game was obviously designed to be much more tame and mellow.

Gameplay is rather short, but, it still packs an emotional punch that'll leave a melancholy and bittersweet imprint. I was also overjoyed when I found out that Freebird Games was making a new game, called Finding Paradise, which will delve into the dying mind of the man who was the little boy in A Bird Story. So, it appears that A Bird Story is the prequel to Finding Paradise. That being said, I definitely suggest that anyone who loves To the Moon or is planning to play Finding Paradise checks this out. However, even as a stand alone game, this is a very sweet and bittersweet little game that'll no doubt tug on your heartstrings regardless of whether or not you have played To the Moon or are planning to play the sequel, Finding Paradise. 

Freebird Games (the makers of the games I've been mentioning in this review) know how to make games that bring out raw and unadulterated emotions in people. Their games will make you cry, they will make you think about life, loss, death, and everything in between. I won't spoil the ending, so, I'll say as much as I can say without ruining the plot too much. In short, this is a story about a little boy who was lonely. Then, he made a new friend. A bird. And, for a while, they were inseparable and they were the best of friends.

I was a little concerned when Kan Gao said that A Bird Story would be divisive amongst fans of To the Moon. I am a fan of To the Moon. And thats what people need to understand. Sure, as a standalone game, it's only an 8 out of 10, a solid B. Well, that was a wasted hour. A Bird Story isn't a game. It's a little pixel-art movie that sometimes interrupts your watching to make you press a few buttons. But only one or two buttons, before slowly fading back to the movie. I hope you like slow fades to black for no discernable reason! 

The story is bland. The setting is completely undeveloped and offers no reason to try and explore (not that you have control to do so). The other humans in the story are literally just shadow people. There is no character development, because the boy is barely a character at all. He's just a cliche - lonely boy, slightly picked on at school, parents are too busy to pay attention to him. That's it... he's completely one-dimensional. We see a peek that he likes drawing, but other than that there is no personality to be found.

Honestly, I think the people praising this story and talking about how emotional it is are saying that simply because they think they're supposed to, or because it makes them seem deep if they do. There's no substance to this story. But interactive stories like this are popular right now, so it *must* be deep, right? So let's all pretend that it is and say we cried over it.

I think there's promise for the game that's coming (despite the cheesy title). I liked the way reality and imagination blended together. But A Bird Story, as it is, is boring, bland, and very shallow.

Like many people, I played To the Moon before I played this game. I tried to come in without much expectations, and I even knew that it was mostly just a sit-back-and-watch "game." I mean, the title even calls it a story.

However, that ended up not quite true. A Bird Story does have you play, controlling the kid every so often, performing actions that are mostly super slow and tedious. The game basically just pops up with images of items and you have to walk somewhere in a room (or in an adjacent one), grab the item, and return to the original location. That was one piece that really bothered me and added arbitrary time to the story for not much reason at all, making the true length of A Bird Story even shorter.

Essentially, the story is rather predictable and cliche overall, despite the art direction being unique. The child, whose name we never learn because the game has no text or dialogue at all, is a rather lonely kid. He seems to have no friends, though his parent(s) do show love to him from what little we can see. And as the name implies, the game does literally involve a bird, which he befriends.

The game takes just around an hour, maybe a little more, to go through a handful of days of his life with the bird, as far as I can tell. The display is rather surreal, which is definitely a pro. For instance, as you walk around in short bits of the game, the environment will drastically change from the kid's memory, where you'll walk out a door into the forest, and then another door suddenly appears to take you into school. Trees will even move around while you're walking in a few places, forcing you down a certain path.

While I liked that art, as the kid's imagination and memory are all merging together for some uniqueness, those qualities of the game do not save it as a whole. As said above, almost no interaction from us was really worth it, considering the developers threw in many tedious or repetitive tasks, whereas To the Moon did not feel that way.

Really, the game is just trying to get people invested into the kid and his childhood. It is a teaser for the bigger sequel to To the Moon, called Finding Paradise as of right now. That is another reason that bothers me and somewhat explains why I didn't feel like the game brought anywhere near as much of an experience.

Despite the game getting some emotion from me, I think the best description of my experience is to say "I was simultaneously happy, sad, and bored."

28343204.review:
tl;dr Not for everyone. Some may consider this pricey for a mere hour of story. I myself bought it during a sale. If on the fence for any reason, the best deal breaker: Developer supports refunds and no questions asked. Check forums for details.

Kan Gao's (the developer) use of the word "experimental" certainly describes the game well. The "gameplay" and interaction is minimal, even more so than his previous work, To the Moon. With so much of the game on auto pilot, it's hard to decide whether the entire thing should have just been that, and thus a video rather than game, or have more interaction to actually make the interaction meaningful. While the gameplay sometimes felt like it interrupted the narrative more than adding to it, there were more than a few sequences that were fun to control the character.

Its story, both in plot and execution, is worth discussing as well. It was simple enough and exactly as it says on the tin; 'a boy who found an injured bird, told through a blur between reality and imagination'. Surreal in many instances, yet relatable and interesting most of the time. Its initial few minutes were more confusing rather than intriguing, but I was invested once the titular bird appears. To be able to express a range of emotion with sprites is a commendable feat, as well as humour without any text whatsoever.

As ever, its music is a lovely accompaniment to the game and one that I will look forward to listening to in my spare time. The art and rather creative use of assets is something I hope to see more both from Kan Gao and other developers.

In summary, would I recommend the game? The thumbs up above is an obvious yes. It does come with a qualifier however; the game is definitely not for everyone. After finishing it, I was left with mixed feelings. No regret or buyer's remorse, but rather confusion as to what I just experienced. Even with that however, I'd recommend the game to people to encourage more experimentation like A Bird Story, even if they don't always work out. That Kan Gao also understand how divisive and different the game can be, offering full refunds no questions asked, is simply icing on the cake.

It isn't really a video game. It's a short and slow movie in which dialogues are replaced with beautiful music and surreal events, among which reality entwines memories, feelings and dreams. 
For the first 0.5 hours I was pressing buttons a lot in hope I will get any kind of answer from the game or just an interaction, but the truth is the game does not need player to do anything (sometimes you have to move from tile A to tile B or press "Use" key) and it would be much more interesting and immersive if you could just sit back and watch without doing anything from time to time.
The major "writing" issue I have is that the game - focused on a little boy and his pet bird - completely ignores the kid's parents/caretakers. Like in a generic anime TV series - the protagonist may do whatever he wants without any real consequences and even when he upsets his teacher or other authorities, there is nobody who could really call his home and try to discuss the issue. All he need to do is run away and the problem vanishes. Just lazy writing, because of which I couldn't feel to much.
But for many people it is still immersive and impressive story so you may want to look for this "game" (movie) during a sale time.

A Bird Story is a short story driven game about a small boy, in the realm of the shadow people and walking trees, and his best friend who is a bird that he saves from a certain badger death.


Had to get a pic in of the shadow people before I lost you. The walking trees you will just have to see for yourself. The game was over before I knew it but it is told in a very emotionally impactful way. You are lead through the journeys of the the boy and his bird in a very creative and artistic way. The visuals are very much like a retro RPG but it is very much a story book and not a game that you do any wondering of your own.


It can be a bit slow at times, for me it took a while to get going before I felt connected to the story. Once it gets going though it is a delightful experience and has a really wonderful charm to it. If you have a little over an hour to dedicate to it, expect to finish it in the first sitting.


It is definitely a niche type game and you will not get a lot of gameplay out of it by any means. However, if you are looking for a short game to play through and kick back while enjoying a nice little story, this game is worth a look. What it lacks in problem solving and a challenge, it makes up for with a unique charm and a beautifully told story.

A Boredom Simulator would be more fitting title. Yes I have only played 19 minutes of this game and it was enough to make up my mind. One doesn't need to eat tbe entire meal to know it's undercooked and tastes like shit.

It has all the amateurish features most RPG Maker games have. Boring tile-based level design, poor low res SEGA Genesis-style graphics, agonizingly slow camera pans, fade ins and fade outs that take forever and so on. 

I may be mistaken but I think the author tried to convey the feeling of loneliness and maybe to some extent alienation that all kids experience sometimes. If so, then I'm afraid he either wasn't qualified enough to fully express himself or chose the wrong engine. RPG Maker seems to be a simple tool, but it's just too restricting, especially for projects which are more ambitious than your regular j-rpg. A Bird's Story is quite ambitious, in that - as far as I can tell, which is up to 19th minute of the game - there is no text in the game, so the player fills the blanks himself/herself). I guess it belongs to Ambitious Failure category of games, as well as to Incredibly Boring one. 

(For the record, I played To The Moon by the very same game developer and I was quite impressed with it. I've also played few other RPG Maker games which were ok/good, so I know both the author and RPG Maker can deliver)
